161.15.text:
So a white elephant party,
in case you don't know,

163.29.text:
is a party where
you get invited.

164.66.text:
You bring a gift,
and then there's

166.20.text:
like-- it's also called a Yankee
swap for those New Englanders

171.34.text:
And there's usually kind of
a gift that nobody wants,

174.03.text: or some gifts that nobody wants.

175.52.text:
And then it's a game where
you kind of like-- you can

178.31.text: trade the gifts and you barter.

179.70.text:
And you try to
get the good ones.

181.07.text:
And the ones that you don't
want are called white elephants.

184.72.text:
In preparation for
this talk, I actually

186.39.text:
looked up, where
did that come from?

187.89.text:
And it came from the King
of Thailand, back many,

192.09.text:
many centuries ago, used to give
white elephants to the people

197.43.text:
And the reason that he did
was because they were sacred.

202.75.text:
And so they were very
valuable in a way,

205.42.text:
but they were not
allowed to do any work.

207.44.text:
So when you received
a white elephant,

209.85.text:
you had to care for it
for the rest of its life,

211.85.text:
but it couldn't do
anything for you.

213.40.text: So that's where it came from.

to opportunities that come
